thread.title: Olympic snowboarder completes second epic urban stunt
thread.title_full: Olympic snowboarder completes second epic urban stunt

author: Amanda Howard
title: Olympic snowboarder completes second epic urban stunt
text:
Skiing Videos Olympic snowboarder completes second epic urban stunt British park and pipe star Jamie Nicholls rides along, around and through Hemel Hempstead's Snow Centre to pull off another trick-filled run at the indoor slope By Amanda Howard Comments 
British Olympic snowboard slopestyle athlete Jamie Nicholls has done it again. 
The 22 year-old, who came sixth in the snowboard slopestyle final in Sochi last year, completed his second snowboard stunt at Hemel Hempstead’s Snow Centre – but this one was bigger, better and twice as challenging as his previous effort in 2014 . 
This year’s run again took him on, off and around the slopes of the indoor snow centre, but raised the shred cred significantly with seven rather than three features in total, and tricks taking place in some particularly unusual places. 
In the new video, Nicholls starts outside from a scruffy patch of grass at the back of the Snow Centre and heads down a narrow, freshly-laid snow track running the length of the building. 
Jamie Nicholls starts his run on a specially-made track outside the Snow Centre 
He uses a mix of real-snow and urban features to pull off his tricks, which include flipping off a vertical bank of snow built up against a storage container, before riding some railings then heading through the back doors into the Snow Centre to do a series of tricks on the 160m main slope. 
Nicholls finishes the urban slopestyle run in style with a switch frontside rodeo 540 (a front flip with a 540-degree spin in the air), before sliding on to the tarmac in the car park outside. 
• How do freestyle skiers train in summer? 
A team at the Snow Centre worked through the night to build this year’s course for the GB park and pipe star, including moving tons of snow outside the building. The run took more than 17 hours to construct and meant a 4am start for Nicholls to complete filming the following morning. 
The course finishes with a kicker that takes Nicholls over some railings and into the car park 
He said: “I am excited to see if everyone likes my 2015 Hemel run as much as 2014’s footage. It’s definitely bigger and better than last year’s! I just wanted to do something more inspiring that would push the limits of UK snowboarding even further.” 
Nicholls' first crazy route, filmed in 2014, has had more than seven million views . 
Visitors to this year’s Telegraph Ski & Snowboard shows in Manchester (October 30 to November 1) and London (November 5 to 8) can see Jamie Nicholls in person. He’ll be meeting fans at both shows and taking part in live Q&A sessions, plus he may even be hitting Mount Battersea, the London show’s giant real-snow kicker. Tickets are available to book now at skiandsnowboard.co.uk .
